title: I Was Sent to Study a Small Town. It's Very Strange Here.
full_text:
The bus wheezed to a stop with a hydraulic sigh that seemed to echo longer than it should have in the mountain air. I gathered my worn leather satchel from the seat beside me, checking that my recorder and notebooks were still secure in the main compartment. Three hours of winding roads had brought me here to Harksworth, a place that existed more as a rumor than a destination on most maps. I stepped down onto cracked asphalt, and the bus driver gave me a look that suggested I might be making a mistake. The doors closed behind me with finality, and I watched the vehicle disappear around a bend, leaving me alone at what could generously be called a bus stop, really just a weathered signpost and a patch of gravel where the mountain road widened slightly. The silence hit me first, not the peaceful quiet of a small town, but something heavier, more deliberate. I pulled out my phone to check the time, but the screen showed no signal bars, not surprising this far into the mountains, but it made me feel more isolated than I'd expected. I turned toward the village proper and felt my breath catch slightly. Harksworth spread out below me like something from a postcard that had been touched up too many times. Every building looked freshly painted. Every fencepost perfectly straight. Every garden meticulously maintained. The main street ran in a clean line through the center, flanked by shops and houses that seemed to gleam even in the overcast afternoon light. Something was off about the perfection. I'd covered plenty of small mountain communities over the years, and they all had character. Peeling paint here, a sagging porch there, weeds growing through sidewalk cracks, the kind of gentle decay that came with real people living real lives. Harksworth looked like a movie set dressed for filming. I started walking down the main road. My footsteps unnaturally loud on the pristine pavement. The Regional Herald had sent me here to investigate what should've been a simple human interest story. The Luckiest Citizen Award, supposedly given annually to one resident of Harksworth for outstanding community service. It sounded like the kind of heartwarming local tradition that made for easy copy during slow news weeks. But my preliminary phone calls had been strange. Every number I'd tried had been answered with the same careful politeness, the same vague responses, the same reluctance to provide details. People claimed not to know much about the selection process, couldn't remember past winners, suggested I speak to someone else who then gave me the same runaround. After 15 years of journalism, I developed a nose for when people were hiding something. Harksworth residents weren't just being unhelpful. They were being deliberately evasive. The inn appeared ahead of me, a two-story building with a hand-painted sign that read, "Harksworth Inn, est. 1887," in letters that looked like they'd been touched up yesterday. Flower boxes beneath each window overflowed with blooms that shouldn't have been thriving this late in the season. Even the brass door handle gleamed like someone polished it daily. I pushed open the front door and stepped into a lobby that smelled of lemon oil and something else I couldn't identify, something sweet and cloying that made my stomach turn slightly. The interior matched the exterior's obsessive maintenance. Hardwood floors that reflected the overhead lights, furniture that looked antique, but showed no signs of actual wear, walls lined with photographs of village events that all seemed to feature the same forced smiles. A woman emerged from behind the front desk before I'd taken three steps into the lobby. She was around 55 with graying brown hair pulled back in a bun so tight it seemed to stretch the skin around her eyes. Her dress was dark blue with a white apron that looked like it had never seen actual work. "You must be the reporter," she said, and her smile felt like something she'd practiced in a mirror. I stopped walking. "I'm sorry? Frederick Armstrong from the Regional Herald." She moved around the desk with quick, efficient steps. "I'm Avery Day, the proprietor. We've been expecting you." The hair on the back of my neck stood up. I'd made my travel arrangements under my own name, but I'd never contacted the inn directly. My editor had simply told me to find lodging in Harksworth and expense it. There was no reason this woman should know who I was or why I was here. "I haven't made a reservation," I said carefully. "Oh, that's quite all right. We have a room prepared for you." Avery's smile never wavered, but her eyes had gone sharp and watchful. "You're here about the ceremony, I assume?" I set my satchel down and pulled out my notebook, more to buy myself time to think than because I needed to take notes yet. "The Luckiest Citizen Award, yes. I was hoping to speak with some residents about the tradition." The change in Avery's expression was subtle but unmistakable. The practiced smile faltered for just a moment and her hands smoothed down her apron in a gesture that looked automatic and nervous. "It's just a private community celebration," she said, and her voice had gone flat. "Nothing that would interest outsiders, really." "When I called last week, several people mentioned it was quite an honor. I'd love to learn more about how recipients are chosen, maybe speak with this year's winner." Avery's hands were working at her apron again, smoothing fabric that was already perfectly pressed. "I really couldn't say much about the process. Very traditional, you understand? Been the same way for generations."... she was lying. Not about the tradition being old, I could believe that, but about not knowing the details. Everything about her body language screamed that she knew exactly how the selection worked and desperately didn't want to talk about it. "Could you point me towards someone who might know more? A town council member perhaps, or whoever organizes the ceremony?" "I'm afraid I have to see to the kitchen now," Avery said, already backing toward a door behind the front desk. "Your room is number seven, top of the stairs. Key's on the desk there." She disappeared through the door before I could ask another question, leaving me alone in the too perfect lobby with a distinct feeling that I just confirmed something she'd been afraid of. I picked up the old-fashioned brass key marked with a seven and climbed stairs that didn't creak under my weight. Room 7 was as meticulously maintained as everything else I'd seen, a bed with hospital corners, a writing desk that looked unused, curtains that hung in perfect folds. I dropped my satchel on the bed and looked out the window at the village center below. From this height, Harksworth's artificial perfection was even more obvious. The geometric precision of the gardens, the way every building seemed to have been painted in the same month, the complete absence of anything that looked lived in or comfortable. It was like someone had built a museum exhibit of what a mountain village should look like. I grabbed my notebook and headed back downstairs. Avery was nowhere to be seen, which suited me fine. I wanted to talk to residents before word spread that the reporter had arrived, though apparently, that ship had already sailed. The main street stretched out before me like a stage set waiting for actors. A few people moved between the shops, but they walked with purpose. Heads down, no lingering or casual conversation. I approached a middle-aged man coming out of what looked like a general store. "Excuse me," I said, pulling out my press credentials. "I'm Frederick Armstrong with the Regional Herald. I'm here doing a story about your Luckiest Citizen Award." The man looked at my credentials, then at my face, and I watched the same careful mask slide into place that I'd seen on Avery Day. "Jimmy Bailey," he said, extending a hand that was damp with nervous sweat. "I run the shop here." "Great to meet you, Jimmy. Can you tell me how long the award has been part of your community?" Jimmy's eyes darted toward the shop behind him, then back to me. "Oh, I wouldn't know much about that. Been here my whole life, but I don't really pay attention to the... the official things." Another lie. I could see it in the way his shoulders tensed, the way he couldn't quite meet my eyes. This was a man who knew exactly what I was asking about and wished I'd never shown up to ask. "Who would be the best person to speak with about the selection process?" "I really couldn't say." Jimmy was already stepping backward, putting distance between us. "Maybe ask around, see what you can find out." He turned and hurried back into his shop, leaving me standing on the sidewalk with the growing certainty that I'd stumbled onto something much more interesting than a simple community award. I tried three more residents over the next hour, and each conversation followed the same pattern. Initial politeness, careful responses that revealed nothing, and quick exits as soon as they could manage them. A woman named Irene Willis, who'd been tending a garden that looked like something from a magazine, insisted the award was just harmless tradition before suddenly remembering urgent business inside her house. By the time I made it back to the inn, the sun was setting behind the mountains, casting long shadows that made Harksworth's perfection look even more unsettling. I sat at the small desk in my room and spread out my notes, trying to make sense of what I'd learned. Every person I'd spoken with had known who I was before I introduced myself. Every one of them had been prepared for my questions about the award, and every single one had given me responses that were clearly rehearsed to reveal nothing while appearing cooperative. I stared out the window at the village center, now empty except for the warm glow spilling from shop windows. Somewhere down there, people were going about their evening routines, probably talking about the reporter who'd come asking uncomfortable questions, the reporter they'd all somehow known was coming despite my unannounced arrival. I opened my laptop and tried to connect to the internet, but there was no Wi-Fi signal available. The inn's information packet mentioned wireless access, but my computer found nothing. Another small detail that felt deliberate rather than accidental. I flipped through my notes again, looking for patterns, connections, anything that might explain the coordinated evasiveness I'd encountered. One thing was clear. Whatever the Luckiest Citizen Award really was, it wasn't the simple community tradition everyone wanted me to believe. And whatever was happening in Harksworth, the residents were very, very afraid of anyone finding out about it. The realization settled over me like a weight. I'd come here expecting to write a fluff piece about small town values and community spirit. Instead, I'd walked into something that had the entire population scared enough to lie to a reporter's face. I closed my notebook and looked out at the unnaturally quiet street below. Tomorrow, I'd have to dig deeper, push harder, find someone willing to tell me what was really going on.But tonight, sitting in this too perfect room in this too perfect village, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was the one being watched. I needed coffee before tackling another round of interviews, but the inn's dining room had been empty when I checked downstairs. No sign of Avery either, which struck me as odd for what was supposedly a functioning establishment. The whole place felt more like a museum exhibit than a working inn. My notebook from yesterday sat open on the small desk by the window, filled with notes that painted a clear picture of coordinated evasion. Every resident I'd spoken to had known exactly who I was and why I was there, yet none could provide even basic details about their so-called community tradition. That kind of synchronized ignorance didn't happen by accident. I grabbed my satchel and headed out into the morning air. The village looked even more unnaturally perfect in daylight, if that was possible. Every blade of grass seemed trimmed to identical height. Every flower bloomed in precise geometric patterns. It was the kind of place that would photograph beautifully for a tourism brochure, but walking through it felt like being inside a diorama. The Regional Herald had sent me here to write about the Luckiest Citizen Award based on a press release they'd received. "Simple human interest story," they'd said. Feel-good piece about small town values and community recognition. But after yesterday's interviews, I was starting to think the real story was why everyone was so determined to keep me from learning anything about it. I pulled out the crumpled press release from my jacket pocket and reread it while walking. "Jasmine Ortiz, 32, selected as this year's recipient for her outstanding contributions to community welfare." The ceremony was scheduled for tomorrow evening at the Village Center. Standard boilerplate language, nothing that would normally raise red flags, but whoever had written it had been careful to include just enough details to sound legitimate while revealing absolutely nothing substantive. My plan was to find Jasmine Ortiz herself. If she was the current award recipient, she'd have to know more than the evasive non-answers I'd gotten from everyone else yesterday. The press release had mentioned she worked at the local bank, but I figured trying her home first might catch her in a more relaxed setting. Maple Street turned out to be on the village's east side where the houses were noticeably larger and better maintained than the already pristine buildings closer to the center. I checked house numbers until I found the right address, then stopped short when I saw the place. The Ortiz house was impressive in a way that didn't match what I'd expected from a small mountain village. Two stories of recent construction with a wraparound porch and professional landscaping that looked like it belonged in an upscale suburban development. The driveway held a new sedan and a late model pickup truck, both spotless and expensive. For a bank employee in a town this size, Jasmine Ortiz was doing remarkably well for herself. I walked up the flagstone path and knocked on the front door. Through the glass panels on either side, I could see into a spacious entryway with hardwood floors and what looked like genuine antique furniture. This wasn't just comfortable living, this was serious money. The woman who answered the door matched the photo from the press release, though she looked younger in-person. Blonde hair pulled back in a neat ponytail, bright blue eyes, wearing casual clothes that still managed to look expensive. She smiled when she saw me, but there was something guarded about her expression. "You must be the reporter," she said. "Frederick Armstrong, right? From the Regional Herald?" There it was again. I hadn't called ahead, hadn't made an appointment, but somehow she knew exactly who I was and why I was there. Just like everyone else in this place. "That's right," I said. "I was hoping we could talk about the award ceremony tomorrow. Congratulations, by the way." Her smile brightened, though it still didn't quite reach her eyes. "Thank you. Please, come in. I was just making tea." She led me through the entryway into a living room that confirmed my impression about their financial situation. The furniture was all high-end pieces arranged with the kind of casual precision that suggested either professional decorating or someone with naturally excellent taste. Family photographs covered the mantle piece and side tables, showing Jasmine with a dark-haired man I assumed was her husband and a young girl with blonde curls who had to be their daughter. "Beautiful home," I said, settling into an armchair that probably cost more than my monthly rent. "You've done well for yourself." "We've been very fortunate," she said, disappearing into what I assumed was the kitchen. "The award has brought us so many blessings." I pulled out my notebook and looked around while she was gone. The photograph showed a progression over time, from what looked like a modest apartment to increasingly nice setting, culminating in shots taken in this house. The family looked happy in all of them, but there was something about the most recent photos that struck me as almost too perfect. The lighting was flawless. The poses, natural, but somehow idealized, like they'd been taken by a professional photographer who specialized in creating images of domestic bliss. Jasmine returned with a tea service that matched the rest of the house's upscale aesthetic. Fine china, silver spoons, everything arranged on a tray that looked like it belonged in a magazine spread.She poured carefully, her movements precise and practiced. "So tell me about the award," I said, accepting the delicate cup she offered. "How long have you lived in Harksworth?" "Three years now," she said, settling into the chair across from me. "We moved here from the city after Kyle got offered a position with the Forestry Service. Best decision we ever made." I made notes while she talked, but I was watching her face more than writing. Unlike the other residents I'd interviewed, she seemed genuinely willing to discuss her situation. Maybe being the current recipient gave her more latitude to talk, or maybe she was just more confident than the others. "The award came as a complete surprise," she continued. "I mean, I'd heard about it, of course. Everyone in the village knows about the tradition, but I never imagined I'd be selected." "How does the selection process work?" I asked. "Who decides?" For just a moment, her smile faltered. She took a sip of tea, and I noticed her hand was less steady than it had been a moment before. "It's a community decision," she said. "The village council meets and discusses potential recipients. They look for people who've made meaningful contributions to local life." It was the same kind of vague non-answer I'd gotten from everyone else, but delivered with more polish. I pressed a little harder. "What kind of contributions did you make? Community service? Volunteer work?" "Oh, the usual things," she said, waving a hand dismissively. "Helping with church events, organizing fundraisers, that sort of thing. Nothing too exciting." I wrote that down, though it still didn't explain much. "And the award itself, what does it involve? Is there a monetary component or is it purely ceremonial?" That's when I saw the first real crack in her composure. Her teacup rattled slightly against the saucer as she set it down, and her eyes darted toward the large window that looked out toward the forest beyond the village's eastern edge. "It's more than money," she said quietly. "The award brings good fortune, real tangible improvements to your life. Things start going your way in ways you never expected." Now we were getting somewhere. I leaned forward slightly, keeping my voice conversational. "Can you give me some examples?" She looked at the family photographs on the mantelpiece, and her expression softened with what looked like genuine affection. "Everything changed after I was selected," she said. "Kyle had been passed over for promotion twice, but suddenly his supervisor recommended him for a regional manager position. The pay increase was substantial. Then we found this house, and the previous owners were motivated to sell quickly. So we got it for a fraction of what it should have cost." She gestured around the elegant living room. "My own career took off too. I'd been a teller at the bank for two years with no advancement prospects. But within months of receiving the award, I was promoted to assistant manager, then to branch manager. And Sadie," she paused, looking at a photo of the blonde girl. "We'd been trying to have children for years with no success. The doctor said it was unlikely we'd ever conceive naturally, but three months after the ceremony, I was pregnant. Sadie was born perfect, healthy, beautiful. Everything we'd dreamed of." I wrote quickly, trying to capture not just her words, but the way her voice had changed as she talked about these developments. There was genuine warmth there, real gratitude and love for her family. But underneath it, something else was building, a tension that hadn't been there when she'd first invited me in. "That's quite a string of good luck," I said. "All of this happened after you received the award?" "Within the first year," she confirmed. "It was like every door that had been closed suddenly opened. Every obstacle disappeared. We went from struggling to make ends meet to living better than we'd ever imagined possible." The rational part of my mind was already working through the logical explanations. Coincidence, confirmation bias, the kind of positive thinking that could create self-fulfilling prophecies. But the journalist in me was more interested in the story she was telling and the way she was telling it, because despite the obvious happiness these changes had brought her, Jasmine Ortiz was getting more nervous by the minute. Her hands had developed a slight tremor that she was trying to hide by keeping them folded in her lap. Her glances toward the window were becoming more frequent, and each time she looked that direction, her expression tightened with what looked suspiciously like fear. "It sounds like the award has been wonderful for your family," I said carefully, "though I have to say you seem a bit anxious talking about it." She laughed, but it came out forced and brittle. "Anxious? No, not at all. Why would I be anxious?" "You keep looking toward the window," I pointed out. "And your hands are shaking." That's when everything changed. The polite controlled facade she'd been maintaining cracked completely. Her teacup clattered against the saucer as she set it down with hands that were now visibly trembling. She stood up abruptly and walked to the window, peering out at the tree line with an expression that could only be described as haunted. "You shouldn't be here," she said, her voice dropping to barely above a whisper.
"You need to leave Harksworth tonight." I stayed in my chair, but every instinct I developed in 15 years of journalism was suddenly alert. This was the moment when sources either opened up completely or shut down permanently. How I handled the next few minutes would determine whether I learned anything useful or found myself facing another wall of evasion. "Why should I leave?" I asked quietly. "What are you afraid of?" She turned from the window to face me, and I saw genuine terror in her eyes. Not discomfort, not nervousness, but the kind of deep primal fear that people felt when they believed they were in real danger. "The ceremony is tomorrow night," she said. "You can't be here for the ceremony." "What happens at the ceremony?" "I can't tell you that." She wrapped her arms around herself, a defensive gesture that made her look smaller and younger. "Some stories aren't meant to be told." I set down my own tea cup and pulled out my phone, checking the time. "There's an evening bus that stops at the village entrance, right? 7:30?" She nodded eagerly. "Yes, you could catch it tonight. Go back to your newspaper, write that the award is just a nice community tradition, nothing newsworthy. Everyone would be happy with that story." "Including you?" The question seemed to hit her like a physical blow. She sank back into her chair, and for a moment, I thought she might start crying. "It doesn't matter what would make me happy," she said. "What matters is that you pack your things and get on that bus." I leaned forward, keeping my voice gentle but persistent. "Jasmine, I can see that you're frightened. If something's wrong here, if you need help, I might be able to do something about it. But you have to tell me what's going on." She shook her head violently. "You don't understand. This isn't the kind of problem that gets solved by newspaper articles or outside intervention. This is bigger than that, older than that." "Older how?" Another glance toward the window, this one longer and more fearful than the others. Whatever she was looking for out there, she was terrified of seeing it. "The award isn't new," she said finally. "It's been happening for generations. Every year, someone is chosen. Every year, they receive good fortune beyond anything they could have imagined. And every year..." She trailed off, unable or unwilling to finish the sentence. "Every year what?" I pressed. "You need to leave," she repeated, standing up again. "Please, pack your things and catch the evening bus. Don't ask any more questions. Don't try to attend the ceremony. Just go." I could see that I'd pushed as far as she was willing to go. The fear in her voice was real, and whatever was driving it ran deeper than simple reluctance to talk to a reporter. She was genuinely terrified, not just for herself, but apparently for me as well. "All right," I said, closing my notebook and standing up. "Thank you for the tea and for talking with me." She walked me to the door, her movements quick and nervous. As I stepped onto the porch, she caught my arm. "Promise me you'll leave tonight," she said urgently. "Promise me you won't try to stay for the ceremony." I looked into her frightened blue eyes and saw a desperation that made my chest tight. Whatever was happening in Harksworth, Jasmine Ortiz believed it was dangerous enough to risk begging a complete stranger to flee. "I'll think about what you've said," I told her. It wasn't the promise she wanted, but it was all I was prepared to give. She released my arm and stepped back, already shaking her head. "That's not good enough," she whispered. "But I can't make you understand. I can only warn you." She closed the door between us with a soft but final click. I walked back down Maple Street with Jasmine's desperate warnings echoing in my head. Her terror had been real, the kind of fear that made someone grab a stranger's arm and beg them to flee. But instead of scaring me away, her reaction convinced me I was onto something significant. Whatever happened at these ceremonies, it was serious enough to transform a confident bank manager into someone who jumped at shadows. The afternoon stretched ahead of me with new purpose. I pulled out my notebook and flipped to a fresh page, writing "Previous Winners" at the top. If this award had been happening for generations as Jasmine claimed, there should be other recipients in town. Finding them might give me the full picture she'd been too frightened to provide. I started with the most logical approach, returning to the village center and asking direct questions. The general store seemed like the best place to begin since Jimmy Bailey had lived here his entire life according to our brief conversation yesterday. The bell above the door chimed as I entered his shop. Bailey looked up from behind the counter where he was arranging candy bars with unnecessary precision. His face tightened when he saw me, but he managed a strained smile. "Back again, Mr. Armstrong?" "I'm hoping you can help me with something." I approached the counter, keeping my tone casual. "I'm trying to get a broader perspective on the Luckiest Citizen Award. Could you point me towards some previous winners? I'd love to speak with them about their experiences." Bailey's hands stilled on the candy display. He didn't meet my eyes. "Previous winners?" "From past years. This tradition has been going on for a while, right?" "Well, yes, but..." He straightened up and wiped his palms on his apron.... most of them have moved away. You know how it is. People get restless, wanna try new places. All of them moved away? "The ones I can think of, yes." His voice had that same rehearsed quality I'd heard from everyone yesterday. "Sorry, I can't be more helpful." I tried a different angle. "What about from when you were younger? Surely you remember some winners from your childhood." Bailey started rearranging the same candy bars again. "Memory isn't what it used to be, and I should really get back to inventory." He turned away from me, making it clear the conversation was over. I bought a pack of gum I didn't want and left, adding his name to my growing list of evasive responses. The pattern repeated itself at every stop I made. Irene Willis claimed she'd only lived in Harksworth for five years and didn't know about previous awards. A man tending his garden said the winners had moved on to bigger things, but couldn't provide names or details. An elderly woman walking her dog insisted she had poor memory for such things and hurried away before I could ask followup questions. By late afternoon, I'd spoken with eight different residents. Every single one claimed either ignorance or convenient memory loss about past award recipients. The coordinated nature of their responses was becoming impossible to ignore. You don't get this level of consistent evasion without preparation. I found myself back at the inn as the sun started its descent behind the mountains. Avery was behind the front desk, updating what looked like a guest ledger with meticulous handwriting. She glanced up when I entered, her expression guarded. "How was your day, Mr. Armstrong?" "Educational." I approached the desk, deciding to try direct pressure. "I've been looking for previous Luckiest Citizen winners to interview. Funny thing, everyone tells me they've all moved away. Every single one." Avery's pen stopped moving. "People do leave small towns." "All of them? Not one stayed to enjoy their good fortune here in Harksworth?" She set down her pen and looked at me directly for the first time since I'd arrived. Her blue eyes held a mixture of wariness and something that might have been resignation. "What exactly are you trying to find, Mr. Armstrong?" "The truth about what happens at these ceremonies." The silence stretched between us. Avery's fingers drummed once against the desk surface before she caught herself and stilled them. "Some truths are dangerous," she said finally. "Is that a warning or a threat?" "It's practical advice." She picked up her pen again, but didn't resume writing. "There are older residents who might have better memories than most. Glenn Dominguez has lived here longer than anyone." The admission seemed to surprise her as much as it did me. She immediately looked like she regretted the words. "Where would I find Mr. Dominguez?" Avery hesitated, then sighed. "Pine Street, last house on the left, but I didn't send you there." "Understood." I headed upstairs to grab my recorder and check my notes before making this potentially crucial contact. If Glenn Dominguez was Harksworth's oldest resident, he might remember previous ceremonies and winners. More importantly, if Avery had reluctantly given me his name after persistent questioning, she might believe he was someone who could or would tell me the truth. Pine Street turned out to be a narrow road that curved away from the village center toward the tree line. The houses here were smaller and older than those on Maple Street with the weathered look of buildings that had seen decades of mountain winters. I walked past modest cottages with small yards until I reached the last house on the left. Glenn Dominguez's home was a single story structure with faded blue paint and a covered porch that sagged slightly at one corner. The yard was neat, but not obsessively maintained like the rest of the village. Real grass grew here with natural variations in height and color that made it look authentically lived in. I climbed the wooden steps and knocked on the front door. After a long moment, it opened to reveal a man who had to be in his late 70s. He was tall, but stooped with wispy white hair and deep set gray eyes that studied me with sharp intelligence. His lined face showed the weathering of someone who'd spent years outdoors. And his clothes, worn sweater and comfortable slacks, suggested he valued practicality over appearance. "You'd be the reporter," he said without preamble. "Frederick Armstrong, Regional Herald. Are you Glenn Dominguez?" "I am." He continued studying me with those penetrating eyes. "Avery sent you my way, did she?" "She mentioned you might have better memories than most about Harksworth's history." Glenn made a sound that might have been amusement. "That's one way to put it." He stepped back from the door. "Come in then. If we're going to have this conversation, we might as well do it properly." I followed him into a living room that felt like stepping back in time. The furniture was old but well-maintained with doilies on the armrests and antimacassars on the chair backs. The walls were covered with framed photographs spanning what looked like decades of Harksworth life. Groups of people at various gatherings, seasonal celebrations, church events, a visual history of the community. "Sit," Glenn said gesturing to an armchair while he settled into what was clearly his preferred spot by the window. "Can I offer you something to drink? Coffee? Something stronger?" "Coffee would be great,""Actually," he said, reconsidering. "I think I'll have whiskey. This conversation calls for it. You can have coffee if you prefer, but I suspect you'll want something stronger before we're done." Something in his tone made me change my mind. "Whiskey sounds fine." Glenn moved to a small cabinet and poured two glasses of amber liquid from a bottle that looked like it had been around as long as he had. He handed me one and returned to his chair, taking a sip before speaking. "So you want to know about the Luckiest Citizen Award? Everyone else seems determined not to talk about it." "Can't blame them for that." Glenn took another sip and studied me over the rim of his glass. "Question is whether you're someone who can handle the truth. Most people can't." "Try me." Glenn was quiet for a long moment, his gray eyes never leaving my face. I had the sense I was being evaluated, that he was weighing something important in his mind. "You've been asking about previous winners," he said finally. "Yes." "I'm told they all moved away." "That's what people say." Glenn set down his glass and leaned back in his chair. "Been saying it for decades. Easier than explaining what really happened to them." My pulse quickened, but I kept my voice steady. "What really happened to them?" Glenn gestured toward the photographs on his walls. "Take a look at those pictures, Mr. Armstrong. Tell me what you notice." I stood and examined the framed images more carefully. They showed groups of villagers at various events spanning what appeared to be several decades, based on the clothing and photographic quality. As I studied them, a pattern began to emerge. "There are people in the older photos who don't appear in the newer ones," I said. "That's right. And not because they aged out or died natural deaths." Glenn's voice had taken on a gravelly quality. "They were chosen." I returned to my chair, the whiskey suddenly tasting sharper. "Chosen for what?" Glenn picked up his glass again and took a longer drink this time. When he spoke, his words came slowly, as if he was choosing each one carefully. "Harksworth wasn't always the prosperous little community you see today. Generations ago, this was a struggling farming village. Harsh winters, poor soil, failed crops year after year. People were leaving, businesses closing. We were dying as a community." He paused, looking out the window toward the tree line visible in the distance. "Then the Luckbringer came." "The what?" "That's what we called him. Still do, those of us old enough to remember the stories our grandparents told." Glenn's eyes returned to mine. "Mysterious figure who appeared one winter when things were at their worst. Made the village an offer." The room felt colder suddenly, though I knew it was just my imagination. "What kind of offer?" "Prosperity in exchange for tribute. Annual tribute." Glenn's weathered hands gripped his glass tighter. "One person each year would go to live with him in the forest. In return, our harvests would flourish. Our businesses would thrive.
